utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Welcome to "Watters' World." I'm Jesse Waters. We should be used to it by now. The Democrats, pollsters, the media, they've been wrong about President Trump every day for the last three years. Remember in 2016, they said the billionaire from New York didn't stand a chance at just getting the nomination.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: He's not going to be the nominee.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Let's hope that. I don't know, I mean --

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: He's not. As much as we would like it, he's not going to be the nominee because he's just made himself unelectable in a general election.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: He is not going to be the nominee.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But one debate at a time, he took down each of his Republican rivals until he was the last man on stage. Then came the general and they said Crooked Hillary was going to smoke him.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: I also don't think you can win the presidency, frankly, by alienating or beginning to alienate key constituencies.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: That's a guy who knows he's going to lose. That's a guy who knows -- you start talking that way and, again, I don't know that he's ever wanted to win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But again, he proved them wrong. He outran her, outdebated her, and outsmarted her and he bust through the blue wall. So once elected, the media predicted anarchy, economy crashing, remember?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: There always seems to be that niggling, lingering risk in people's minds that the U.S. Is at the end, the mature end of the current cycle, and that a recession could strike at some point either in 2018 or in 2019.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then they said we'd be at war with the North Koreans.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: The current language of the administration, the lack of a diplomatic and serious engagement strategy, in my view, has us sliding toward war by next summer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But the stock market has hit all-time highs. Job numbers up, unemployment down and America not really engaged in major shooting wars. At every turn, as critics have tried to take Trump down -- remember the Mueller investigation?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Evidence is mounting for the president's meddling in the Russia probe.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: This cloud about collusion with Russia will hang over him no matter where he stands.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: They were eager to collude with Russia.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: The president of the United States and those around him during an election campaign colluded with a hostile foreign power.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Does look like collusion.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No collusion. They were all wrong and no obstruction. And now they're at it again with impeachment.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: This testimony is incredibly damaging.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: I can't emphasize how explosive this is.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Very explosive.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: So explosive.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Completely devastating.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: I think Gordon Sondland's testimony today changed everything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, it didn't. And these are the same people that predict we're all going to die in 12 years.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: The world is going to end in 12 years if we don't address climate change, like this is the war. This is our World War II.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No wonder nobody takes them seriously. Nothing. Nothing the left has said has come true. Why would we believe them now? Here with reaction, Fox and Friends co-host Brian Kilmeade, author of the new book "Sam Houston and the Alamo Avenger" and syndicated columnist and Fox News contributor Deroy Murdock. So over the last three years, Brian, none of this stuff has panned out. And that's why these polls don't move on impeachment -- is the people just don't trust what they're hearing anymore.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN KILMEADE, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: And the thing is, Jesse, they don't follow like we follow it. We follow it every day. You know, you doing The Five, you're doing this show. We're all over it. You take one hour off, we're onto it. But if you travel the country and have a chance to do that, with the book tour in particular, I go to Oklahoma, go to Nebraska, go to Texas. They're not following it. And so they don't get upset. They're not changing their mind. In fact, when they view it, it has made the Trump supporters more determined. It made the ambivalent Trump supporters more determined because they see an unfairness to it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you think that that's true with the rest of the country in Trump land? Trump being besieged 24/7 by all this stuff. Do you think that hardens their allegiance towards the president?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I think it does. I think the last survey I saw is something like 90 to 95 percent of Republicans are supporting Trump and behind him after the impeachment thing, they see him being victimized over nothing, over a call that might be a little bit unusual, but nothing illegal or impeachable. And in the view of an increasing number of people, we've seen since the impeachment hearing started, support for impeachment has fallen, opposition has gone up. And even among particularly Independents, it's collapsed something like 13 to 15 points.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And it's amazing.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So, this has absolutely boomeranged in their faces.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, you know, CNN's been pushing this impeachment thing very hard. And once it didn't move the needle, you know who they blamed? They blamed Trump supporters. Listen to this cult language.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: The word "cult" has been popping up more and more. Think back to two weeks ago on this program, Anthony Scaramucci talked about his claim that Trump supporters are in a cult. Just last week, Dan Rather said he thinks support for Trump seems increasingly cultish. And this weekend in The Washington Post, Trump critic and Republican strategist John Weaver said the GOP is not a party anymore in the traditional sense. It's a cult.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So CNN says you've got to impeach the president. The public says not really. And they said, you know what, you're a cult.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: What has happened is -- it doesn't astound me when you have Don Trump Jr. come out for his dad. It doesn't astound me when Mark Meadows comes out for his dad. What astounds me, and it's obviously not a cold, is when you have guys like Ron Johnson -- he made his money in plastics, from Wisconsin. And yet he's going to bat for this Ukraine thing. When you have Senator Thune, you know, from South Dakota, he goes, you know, I never really knew him, but now I get a chance to knew him because you treat him so unfairly it makes people double down. And I think what happens is people throw up their hands and they either say I was wrong or something unbelievable is taking place. They're mystified.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. And CNN can't believe that they weren't able to convince any Republicans in the House or the Senate that Trump should be impeached. So they just smear them instead.

utterances.speaker: DEROY MURDOCK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: They smear those Republicans and, frankly, 63 million people who voted for Trump. That's a pretty big cult, don't you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a big cult.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCK
utterances.utterance: Half the electorate, approximately.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCK
utterances.utterance: And look, I watched the hearings carefully. I think you guys did. Many people did. And we're waiting for a crime. Show me the evidence of the crime. You know, if I saw evidence of a crime, I might say, well, this is a problem. But you just heard conjecture. You heard speculation, you heard presumption. And ultimately you got Ambassador Sondland, I think probably the strongest witness the Democrats could put up, ultimately saying under cross-examination, I never heard the president link aid and investigations. I assume that I presume that I didn't hear it. So, again, where's the evidence of any wrongdoing, any criminality? In the absence of that, people are going to say, look, I don't see any reason he ought to be impeached. If that's the definition of a cult, I guess that's a cult.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is funny that when the Democrats support Barack Obama, it's party discipline.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When the Republicans support Donald Trump, it's a cult. And I remember, I mean, the Democratic Party really circled the wagons around Barack Obama to the point where Barack Obama could say and he honestly believed this, that I did not have any scandals in eight years.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But if you think about it, Barack Obama was great. The president was great at getting himself elected. But what happened around him? Little by little, he lost, he's -- down 60 votes in the Senate. Then he lost the Senate. Then he lost the House. Then he wins reelection by smearing Mitt Romney, not by running on his record. Got great personal presence. You know that. He's got great charisma. Nobody doubts that, talented, wonderful story. But he never talked about that. Then he loses both chambers and he loses the White House. And people say, well, he left a hero. Not really. He left carnage.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he did not leave the Democratic Party in very good standing. I think it was the weakest position electorally they've been in since like the 1920s.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCK
utterances.utterance: I think they lost something like a thousand or 1,100 seats -- congressional seats and state house seats, local seats, etc. So so the Democrat Party is much weaker when Obama went out the front door. And one thing with the media, I think they do themselves a lot of good and they maybe build up their credibility a little bit. If they weren't 100 percent negative or, according to Harvard, I think it's like 96 percent negative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCK
utterances.utterance: For example, Dow at 28,000. Quite a milestone. Zero coverage on ABC, CBS, and NBC evening news. Now you can say -- you can bring in people who are not the market and say, look, a lot of people are benefiting, some people are not investors. That's a fair story. They just ignore things. So when it's all negative, negative, negative, it's the boys and the girls crying wolf five nights a week, seven nights a week..

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They ignore the good and they hype the bad. Brian has got the new book, The Alamo Avengers.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: What I want to do is bring Texas into the mainstream. You know, we grew up in the Northeast. Where'd you grow up?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCK
utterances.utterance: Los Angeles, California.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So, we thought that was their story. It's really our story, and I thought 60 years after the Revolution, if I tell you there's an unfathomable victory, and a group of guys got together to fight for freedom and liberty, and I told you that they were all Americans, and they won back Texas -- eventually, nine years later, they become part of America, without which we wouldn't have had the South or the West -- and then when you see that valor, I thought it'd be worth putting in a book, worth maybe even making the set of Watters World.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes [laughs], I think this is the peak of your career now, right?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right. I wouldn't doubt it. I'm hoping to maybe get on Judge Pirro – -- but if that doesn't happen, this will be the peak.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She's coming up next, all right? You could go [unintelligible] --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Should I stick around and just hope they call my name?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Stick around.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCK
utterances.utterance: This would be a good Christmas and Hanukkah gift.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I would do it, and, Deroy, if you were asking for a discount, five percent off for you, or at least four percent [unintelligible].

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, what a capitalist.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: If you like American stories.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Brian, Deroy, thank you guys.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCK
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Next, bestselling author James Patterson is here. He was Jeffrey Epstein's neighbor in Palm Beach. He had three private eyes look all over this guy, and he's going to share what he found with us. And later, nothing says holiday tradition like a Watters World Thanksgiving quiz.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When the Pilgrims got here, where did they land?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: South [unintelligible].

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very suspicious circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death. About four months ago, while he was in federal prison, Epstein allegedly committed suicide. Many people, including some top forensic guys, don't even believe it, though. People think he had a lot of enemies. Bestselling author James Patterson knows all about Jeffrey Epstein. He was actually one of his neighbors in Palm Beach, and he wrote a very detailed book about Epstein's scandals called Filthy Rich, where he had three private eyes dig into the case. Patterson also has a new book called Crisscross, the latest in the Alex Cross series, and he joins me now. So, James, looking back, let's start from the beginning. How did Jeffrey Epstein make all of his money?

utterances.speaker: JAMES PATTERSON, AUTHOR
utterances.utterance: He did a lot of investments for people, and he also indicated that he could save them a lot on taxes. And he went in, and he said, “Look, I can save you all this money. Otherwise, you're going to have to pay the government. But I want a big piece of it.” That seems to be the biggest part of it. Now we get into the issue of whether he was involved in trafficking of girls around the world. That's, I think, the latest saga and the latest thing. We'll see how that plays out [inaudible] --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, that's -

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: -- himself.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- how he ingratiates himself with powerful people. He goes to these --

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, you don't know. Right, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We think he goes to, like, a billionaire, and he says, “Listen, I can save you a boatload of money on taxes. You give me a flat fee,” and that's how he gets a lot of his money.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Or, “Give me a fee, a flat fee,” yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: “Give me some of the action.”

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. So --

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: We think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We think. So, he obviously has a lot of money. He's in and around Palm Beach, and he has this strategy for, I guess, recruiting young girls from high schools in the area, very, very manipulative strategy. He kind of got one girl to recruit another girl; they would get paid cash. How did that all come to be?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, I think the amazing thing is that, I mean, there literally were hundreds of underage girls. There were certainly over a hundred that were recruited. He got some kids that would go in and recruit other kids from their high school or junior high school, and these kids range from 14, 15, 16. He apparently did not want older girls at all, which is interesting. He -- the way the girls were instructed is when they came to see him they had to say they were over 18, like that's going to matter. And you know, now we have a lot of the girls; they're grown up. And The Miami Herald -- I mean, actually, in the book we had the police interviews with these -- when they were kids, when they were 14, 15, 16 years, the police interviews, which are pretty devastating.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. So, the police -- the local guys had a lot of this locked down. They had interviews; they had testimony; they had hard physical evidence that they obtained from his creepy little lair there in Palm Beach. They had pictures, all this crazy stuff.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: The chief -- the police chief there, Reiter, and Detective Recary -- and they really did -- they were the only ones, to me, through most of this thing who really cared about the girls. They said, “This is wrong. This is a terrible thing.” They're both dads, and they hung with that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. And then they got stifled when they'd go to the state's attorney, and the state's attorney did not --

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I think it got stifled earlier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- want to take this as seriously as the locals.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I think it -- no, I think the locals had problems, too. I think the locals --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because he was throwing money around.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I -- well, I think it was a combination of things. First of all, well, he brought in this dream team with Alan Dershowitz and Black and a few others, and I think the locals got very frightened that they could lose the case. I think what they said was, one, Epstein has already taken care of some of these girls, so they're not going to talk. Secondly, you're not going to be able to prove some of them were ever in his house, and the ones you can prove, we feel we're going to eviscerate them on the witness stand.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, discredit them, tarnish you --

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: And you could lose, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay. And they didn't want to risk that, but they did have him on one count, correct?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, that was all that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Later on.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: -- the local attorney, when he brought it to -- which was the only time a case like this was ever brought to a grand jury like this. The local -- and they brought him up on one charge of prostitution, essentially.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. And the sweetheart deal. People have no idea how sweet this deal was. He was allowed to come and go almost as he pleased from the local cell.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, and they also excused the co-conspirators.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, and we'll never know who they are, or is that going to come out?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, we know that Ghislaine Maxwell was involved in some way, shape, or fashion, and now --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And she was who, exactly?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: -- [inaudible] chasing her down. Well --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She was the daughter of a wealthy publisher.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Maxwell, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And what was her role, Maxwell?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, it's a little unclear except that she and Jeffrey were clearly best, very good friends. They spend amazing amounts of time together, according to the girls and now the women. Ghislaine was very involved in terms of recruiting the girls. TBD. We'll see how that -- but a lot of the girls say that she was involved. Some of them claim that she was involved in some of the sex sessions. TBD in terms of that. But she definitely was around. She definitely was close to Jeffrey.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And do we know if she's --

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: And now she's kind of disappeared.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She has disappeared. Is she ever going to be interviewed again?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, you get the stories now. The FBI wants to talk to her and then you got Prince Andrew over in England with that --.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a disaster.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I know, I know. I know. He was the one who clearly, when we put the book together and had the investigators out there looking, it wasn't clear what he had done, but it was clear that he was really involved. He was at a lot of parties.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very close.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: With Epstein.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And we also know he was close with Bill Clinton, with Donald Trump. The media seems to be very into these angles, as well.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: [Unintelligible] Yeah, I'm not too keen on that in this sense. OK. Let's take President Trump. I talked to the head of the spa from a woman who ran the spa at Mar-a-Lago and I talked to a couple of times. I said did you know Jeffrey Epstein? She said, "oh, yes." She said, "Mr. Epstein came to the spa and he was inappropriate," in her opinion, with the young girls. And she went to and that point, just Donald Trump. And when he heard about it, he banned Epstein from the club.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. So Trump bans Epstein from the club.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: So I don't -- yeah so we never get anything really negative about either he or President Clinton in terms of anything. Zero.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: None of your investigators found anything right [unintelligible]?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: No. And we talked to pilots of his plane or his plane, he had a couple of planes and a helicopter, Epstein did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: And we talked to pilots and they, you know, said no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. So you have talked to pilots?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Because the pilots went to --

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I didn't but the investigators did, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The pilot went to his private island many, many times with many, many people. We know many girls were there. And I mean, there's pictures now of girls on the island. And none of the pilots that you've interviewed ever named any high-profile people that had gone on the plane with them to the island?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: No. Not the pilots that we talked to. No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay and Bill Clinton, obviously, Amy Robach fingered and said we had the goods, we had a Clinton angle, so to speak, when she spoke to that one young victim that ABC spiked. And now it looks like ABC is really hushed up about this. Are you alarmed by that part of the story?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Once again, we never got and obviously I didn't want to, but we never got anything that implicated either President Trump or President Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Now, as it stands today, it looks like the FBI wants to talk to Prince Andrew. Do you believe Prince Andrew, if he does come in for an FBI interview, will shed light on any sort of co-conspirator situation?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I would be surprised if Prince Andrew comes for an FBI interview.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The last interview didn't go so well with the BBC.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: But you know what, you never know. You never know what's going on here. I mean, I was shocked when I, you know, heard about suicide.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Do you believe that it was suicide or do you believe something else happened?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I believe it was suicide.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Tell me why because we've had Dr. Michael Baden, highly respected, said that it's more indicative of homicidal strangulation.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: You know what? I mean, I think one of the things about this and we're going to keep getting all the conspiracy theories, you know, forever because this thing touched so many people. You had the MeToo angle, which is, in my opinion, this is the worst of the MeToo stories, much worse than Cosby or Epstein.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yep because these were young women. Weinstein.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Or not Epstein; Weinstein. You had the justice system not working at all in terms of what happened to Epstein after the -- you know -- and I think the conspiracy things will keep, so, you know, I could be wrong, but I think he killed himself.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Knowing what you know about this issue, do you see certain soft spots that the investigators could go in? Do you see unfollowed leads, in your opinion, that people need to zero in on that might expose more?

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I think, for a lot of reasons, you'd want to hear more from Wexner.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maxwell. Oh, Wexner.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes, Wexner in terms of the money, how did he get the money, what was the relationship?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Wexner was the billionaire who owns the company that owns the Victoria's Secret.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Victoria's Secret and Limited and clearly was getting a lot of financial advice from Epstein and should be able to tell us a lot about Epstein's money. He -- I don't --obviously, he doesn't want to talk.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I don't blame him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Epstein was using his connection with these modeling people to help recruit from overseas.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the next piece of this thing in terms of large stories is trafficking of young girls.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The trafficking.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible] which has been a big story for a long time. I don't think anybody's really opened that up the way you might be able to open up and that's potentially massive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay. And lastly, the villains involved besides Epstein, we know the guy is an evil man. Who are the primary villains or people in power that you feel who were not responsible in handling the situation.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: I think the local attorneys backed off too early. I don't blame Acosta, honestly, because when he got pulled in and I think the interesting thing about Acosta is that's when the media got on this thing. Really got on it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: They didn't care about the girls. But all of a sudden, "oh, Alex Acosta, the guy who President Trump appointed secretary of labor. Ooh. Who cares about the girls? But we can --" Which is crazy. But that's when this thing really blew up in the media --.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because you finished this book, Filthy Rich, which everybody should read. It's the definitive, in my opinion, piece on the Epstein scandal.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: It's the only piece at this stage.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This was out in 2016. And you said there wasn't a lot of people clamoring for this book.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Well, no, we did fine with the book. But in terms of going out to the media, we couldn't get -- and I'm going like, seriously? I mean, this story is ama -- that's why I wrote the book, because the story is so incredible. And we had most of them and we had, you know, investigations of the president. We had Acosta, we had interviews, you know, police interviews with the girls. We had most of it there. Obviously, we didn't know that Epstein would supply the perfect ending by killing himself. But we had most of the rest.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Now you have the new one, Criss Cross. And this is one of many that you've written about Alex Cross. And tell us what this is about, because this, again, is about justice and the miscarriage of justice and misconduct.

utterances.speaker: PATTERSON
utterances.utterance: Yeah, well, I think the other interesting thing about Criss Cross is on the same day we're bringing Ali Cross, which is his 12 year old son. And I'm so big on trying to get kids reading and having the parents and grandparents interact. So we've got an Alex Cross. And in this book, one of the things that happens is that Alex has to try to save Ali, his son, who gets in some trouble. And Ali Cross, Ali, who's 11, 12 years old, who's watched his father and his stepmother as police people and one of his friends is missing, so he applies some of what he's learned from his father and goes out looking for this missing friend, which I -- and I love that idea and these books came out at the same time. And Ali's been in a lot of the -- the last three or four adult books. So I just liked that idea. Good going, Jenny.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughs] Well, always suspenseful. Always a thrilling read. James Patterson, Filthy Rich and Criss Cross. Here they are. Thank you very much for coming and shedding some light on this stuff. Still ahead, a Watters' World Thanksgiving quiz. But first, Black Friday cast, Americans going to war with each other over deals. What the heck is going on with us?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Last weekend's Harvard-Yale game delayed almost an hour. A bunch of students swarmed the field to protest global warming. About 50 Ivy Leaguers were arrested, the crowd not happy about it. Yale ended up winning by a touchdown in double OT. But this isn't the only time these global warming protesters have inconvenienced people. Remember, in October hundreds of protesters jammed subway stations in London, disrupted everything. One person even climbed on one of the trains. And here in New York City they stopped traffic in the heart of Times Square; they tied themselves to a boat. And in D.C., several protesters stopped a line of cars just waiting to drive through a traffic light. Here for his reaction, we turn to actor Dean Cain. Now, Dean, a part of me just wanted them to just second half and just run these guys over.

utterances.speaker: DEAN CAIN, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: A huge part of me wanted them to do that exact same thing. I played on that field; I played at Princeton, and I hate that field because I lost both times I played there. But those guys work their tails off. Those ballplayers -- they work their tails off. They want to play ball, they want to go, and this is a -- you know, slowing them down for an hour could be detrimental to the players, to their health. You tighten up. It changes everything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, it could have changed the whole outcome of the game if you think about it.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: They really should have let them play. I guarantee those players would have played on, and that field would have cleared really --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughs] I know.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: -- really quickly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know, they would have gotten trucked, and these people don't look like they play sports anyway.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: No, they don't, but you know, that's a hard thing. I mean, they want attention, okay?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's about them.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: It's a bit about them, their signs, but their message wasn't even clear. It's like, you know, relieve the debt on Puerto Rico, and, you know, the Uighurs are getting bad treatment in China.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They don't know what they're protesting.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: But they are very happy to protest.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you know what they did? They trashed the tailgate section.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Of course they did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, look at it. These people care so much about Planet Earth. Look what they did. I mean, you know what they could have done? Instead of going into the 50-yard line, they could have just picked up all the garbage, and that would have been a more carbon-neutral protest.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: A hundred percent, but there's no way that's going to happen. Every one of these climate protests, you see that. They just trash the area.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like on Earth Day, remember?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Have you seen those pictures from Earth Day?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Just stuff piled everywhere. So, it rings hollow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It does.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I will have to say congratulations to Yale, because they were co-Ivy champs, them and Dartmouth, and Princeton was out of it this year.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Sorry about Princeton. All right, we have some footage of some of the best and the worst of these presidential turkey pardons. We wanted to ask Dean about that because he loves to eat turkey.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Roll it.

utterances.speaker: THEN-PRESIDENT BARACK OBAMA
utterances.utterance: The office of the presidency, the most powerful position in the world, brings with it many awesome and solemn responsibilities. This is not one of them.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Look, I had a chance to shoot a bunch of you the other day and didn't.

utterances.speaker: THEN-PRESIDENT GEORGE W. BUSH
utterances.utterance: Biscuits, welcome. Marshmallow and Yam.

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.utterance: Caramel and Popcorn. Tater and Tot.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Drumstick. Peas and Carrots.

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.utterance: I want to take a moment to recognize the brave turkeys who weren't so lucky, who didn't get to ride the gravy train to freedom, who met their fate with courage and sacrifice, and proved that they weren't chicken.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Even though Peas and Carrots have received a presidential pardon, I have warned them that House Democrats are likely to issue them both subpoenas. I can't guarantee that your pardons won't be enjoined by the Ninth Circuit. Always happens.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughs] Very good. Now, people want to get rid of this tradition. They hate that. They're complaining, “Oh, Trump's this big criminal. Why are we pretending we're having fun with these pardons?” I love them.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I think they're hysterical. I mean, even though those moments -- Bill Clinton clapping because, you know, there's a little mess made there --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughs] Yeah.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: -- the one turkey going after George W. Bush -- that was just great stuff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he went below the belt on W.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Hey, taking a shot, taking a shot at him, you know. I think it's hysterical; I think it's fun. It shows a lighter part of the presidency. President Obama was very funny with his things. Bread and Butter, just recently pardoned --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you like that name? I like Tater and Tot.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: That's pretty good. I forgot --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It doesn't get much better than that.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Bread and Butter is good, though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is --

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible] --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're getting hungry right now.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I am very hungry for that. That was pretty awesome. I think it's great fun, and there's -- it's like the no-fun brigade. Why -- it's like with the NFL [inaudible] --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know. Relax, everybody, relax.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Relax.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what's not a lot of fun? If you're trying to go to Best Buy or something like that on Black Friday. You could get your head taken off. I mean, some of these people on Black Friday -- they go in there, and they're trying to kill some people. They want that flat-screen, and they want it bad. I mean, what does it say about the culture that they will literally kill someone to get 50 percent off?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: That is -- it is a very, very frightening reality, but for me, I love Black Friday and these videos --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You do?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: -- because I could sit and watch these for hours.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughs] From the comfort of your own home.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I will never be out on Black Friday. I will just watch it. It's insane to me. It goes to the lower -- the base human emotion of, like, survival, you think, but they're going for a flat-screen TV. It's kind of messed up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what? I'm going to bring you to Black Friday next year. You're going to be my lead blocker.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I will do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just get out in front, and I'll just follow you, all right?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I'll create some space, and we'll walk out with some TVs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sounds good.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thanks very much, Dean. All right. Up next, the busiest travel week of the year. Airplanes become Armageddon. A flight attendant is here to tell us some of the most disgusting and shocking things she's ever seen. Be warned.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A record 32 million people are expected to fly this holiday week, and some of those travelers are straight up animals. I'm not talking about emotional support animals. In fact, passengers are actually the biggest threat to the flight crew. Passengers. And a few months ago, former flight crew manager for Virgin Airlines, Ally Murphy, shared with me some of her secrets from the skies. All right, Ally, what is some of the most inappropriate things that passengers have subjected you to on a flight?

utterances.speaker: ALLY MURPHY, FORMER FLIGHT CREW MANAGER
utterances.utterance: Wow. Inappropriate things. I think the usual sort of tapping on the behind to get my attention. That's kind of inappropriate. I wouldn't tap anybody on the behind for any other reason.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughter].

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: But [unintelligible] you can do that. So things like that. I've had, I've caught passengers trying to sneak into the bathrooms to get --.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The mile-high club.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah. And actually, I remember --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah let me ask you, though, so if you catch someone trying to join the mile high club, do you stop them or do you how do you deal with that?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: It depends if I like them. If they've been nice people and, you know, it's kind of discreet. I think, you know, you kids have fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughs]

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: But --.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible] then they're out of there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK and you work for Virgin Airlines. That's true, OK.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I guess there's different rules. Sometimes you have severely intoxicated people. You know, they're popping pills, they're drinking wine. What are some of the worst things you've seen on that level?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: I think that the worst time for me was a guy who had taken sleeping tablets and then he'd brought -- he'd snuck on his own alcohol. He drunk an entire bottle of wine to himself, little did we know. But the two together, they can kind of create a reaction where you don't actually know what you're doing. You don't sleep, but you have no idea what you're doing. So, this guy, he went around and he stole all the other passengers' shoes and was trying them on and then he sat next to his wife, didn't recognize her. And then he just suddenly thought, I want to get off here. So he tried to open the door, the aircraft door, which of course that meant that we had to then jump on him and restrain him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God. So you jumped on the guy for trying to open the door mid-flight. Did you, what, did you have to put handcuffs on him?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: Well, we were going to. You can't open the door mid-flight. It's not possible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a big no-no.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: Yeah. So we pinned him down. And then he passed out. So then he became a medical situation and we had [unintelligible].

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What happens when someone gets physically aggressive because we've seen tons of videos, people throwing punches, people kicking, people refusing to leave. What's the protocol there?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: The protocol is to try and calm the situation down, which we always will try and do. We have training every year to go through situations where you are trying to defuse the situation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Has someone ever tried to throw a punch at you or any of your colleagues?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: Not me personally, but a couple of my friends, they've received punches, one from a celebrity, actually. That was fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Was it Charlie Sheen?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: No, it wasn't, no. Female celebrity.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Was it Greg Gutfeld?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're not going to tell me who it was, are you?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: I'm not. No. Just because [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. You'll tell me after the commercial break. All right. Listen, it sounds like survival of the fittest up there. I congratulate you for dealing with people so politely. I bet your temper must have been here at some -- did you ever lose your temper real quick?

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: Once when a passenger swore at me and said that it was my fault that the plane was delayed because I'd been doing CPR on a guy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK. Very nice man. Well, thanks for not snapping on everybody. And thanks for your liberal mile high club policy. I think many people would enjoy that. All right, Ali, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: MURPHY
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Up next, one of our favorite traditions, the Watters' World Thanksgiving quiz. Around what year was the first Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: 1942. Columbus sailed the ocean blue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Watters' World quiz, a time-honored tradition. Here's the best and the worst of Thanksgiving trivia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Around what year was the first Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: 1942, Columbus sailed the ocean blue, so --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughs] That was so wrong. [sound effect]

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: 1860? Very close.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What year, around, was the first Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, that was a high five.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: That was a high five. That's what I thought.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Who ate together on the first Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Oh, God, is this one of those quiz shows that make you look dumb?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: White people?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Who were these white people that were eating on the first Thanksgiving? What were they called? The Pil--

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Oh, the Pillsbury?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: The Pilgrims came to America. [sound effect] Americans fed them, welcomed them to our country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, the Pilgrims dined with the Americans?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Yes. [sound effect]

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The American people?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Yes?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What country did the Pilgrims come from?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Oh, God, now you're pushing it. It's been a long time since I've been in grammar school.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Europe?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Europe is not a country.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Sweden. Spain?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Italy? Spain?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Somewhere around there?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Israel?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Israel?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: No?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not Israel. The Pilgrims were not Jewish [laughs]. What country did the Pilgrims come from?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Asia? South America? I don't know. I'm not getting these right now [laughs]. [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How did the Pilgrims get here?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Oh --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What was the name of the boat?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Uh --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What was the name of the boat?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Plymouth? Rock?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: The Nina? The Pinta?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: The Santa Maria?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: The Mayflower. [sound effect]

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Mayflower. [sound effect]

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Excellent. Just right over yonder.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why did the Pilgrims come from England?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: It was to explore the West.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: To spread their empire.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: New land. Gold.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: [laughs]

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: They were from the United Kingdom – -- escaping religious persecution.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you think was on the menu at the first Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Perhaps some sort of local vegetables and maybe meat. Turkey? I don't know. Buffalo? Chicken? I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Maybe wild turkeys – -- pheasants –

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wild Turkey, like the drink?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: No, that probably would have made the dinner a whole lot better, though.

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Oh, hard to say.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Maybe some lobsters – -- turkeys –

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Hush puppies, like, boiled and fried.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How did they fry it? When the Pilgrims got here, where did they land?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: South Carolina.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Virginia?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: New York?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Plymouth Rock.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and where is Plymouth Rock?

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: In Massachusetts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You are incredible.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: I am smart.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you know who I am?

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: No. Who the hell are you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm Watters --

utterances.speaker: MALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Right, Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- and this is my world.

utterances.speaker: FEMALE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: Snap.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Up next, Last Call.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Last Call. This time of year, it's important to reflect on what we're most grateful for -- our health and our families -- but for my next guest, each and every day is a blessing. Sixteen-year-old Matthew Levine has FSGS, a chronic kidney disease that has no known cause or cure. Matthew was diagnosed at just two-and-a-half years old. He takes up to 15 pills a day, and he's probably going to need a kidney transplant. Matthew joins me now with his father, Michael Levine. All right, Matthew, what's life like under these conditions? How does a regular day for you go?

utterances.speaker: MATTHEW LEVINE
utterances.utterance: Well, first, thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Of course. Thanks for coming in.

utterances.speaker: LEVINE
utterances.utterance: Well, it's very hard because I have to take 15 pills a day. I have to watch the amount of salt I eat -- sodium -- and, like, miss out on a lot of activities with friends because I'm tired and fatigued and can't hang out with my friends.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, what kind of activities aren't you able to do?

utterances.speaker: LEVINE
utterances.utterance: Sports. When I was younger, I would play baseball, and some days I'd miss a lot of practices because I was very tired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And as your father, he loves you so much. I met him at an event a little while ago, and, man, you are so lucky to have a dad like that. And he told me about the situation, and I just wanted to come talk to you about it. What's been your kind of greatest moment since you've been kind of thrust into this issue?

utterances.speaker: LEVINE
utterances.utterance: I think, Jesse, the greatest moment is just seeing my son be a hero. I think he just -- he's been a hero to everybody. He's been a hero to everybody. He's been a hero to the children and adults around the world that are afflicted with this horrible kidney, devastating chronic kidney disease and just watching him. He just made a speech at our dinner on November 14th where we raised $1.2 million and we had 700 people and just watching him speak in front of 700 people, as a 16-year-old, has been just an unbelievable thing, to watch something good come out of something that's so bad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Were you nervous when you were up there in front of all these people?

utterances.speaker: LEVINE
utterances.utterance: I was so nervous, but I was able to do it because like I had so many people I love in front of me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Were you more nervous then or on Watters' World right now?

utterances.speaker: LEVINE
utterances.utterance: Right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's nothing to be nervous -- and NephCure is an organization that can help out a lot with this issue.

utterances.speaker: LEVINE
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, as we discussed at that fundraiser, it's www.nephcure.org. Nephcure.org, the only organization in the world trying to find a cure for FSGS nephrotic syndrome and IGA nephropothy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very brave man. Thank you guys very much, Matt, Michael.

utterances.speaker: LEVINE
utterances.utterance: Thanks you so much. I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. That's all for tonight. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. "Justice with Judge Jeanine" is next. And remember, I'm Watters and this is my world.
